item.title: Fuckin' security measures at Heathrow airport
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
As you might imagine, this post is not going to be a charm. Thanks to the new EU law, I just missed my connection and I have to wait for the next flight to Madrid. Fortunately, I just have to wait one hour.But what if there wasn't any place available in that one?How long will people accept any law for some obscure security reasons just like sheep?How many planes have blown up because a passenger had liquid in his hand luggage? How many planes have crashed because a passenger had hidden explosive in a white liquid in a baby milk mug?But you can still take a plane with polium120 as long as you take less than 100ml. Which is more than enough to kill hundreds of persons. Worst, I took the plane with 3 batteries within those two were defect and had a high risk of explosion!!! (see my post about my 3 batteries to know more about those).So don't tell me it is for security reasons all this shit in the european airports.It's just a lobbying to put pressure on people and to let them know that the terrorist threat is always present and that to have to let our parlements vote laws that restrict even more and more our freedom.And by the way, it's also a very good law to hide an increase in the airport taxes. Since now you have to pay 2 euros if you are just a bit thirsty.Duty free should be very happy of this.
2£ for one Coca-Cola... thank you!I remember when that law was voted by the european parliament. I was in Madrid and I was terrified to see in the newspaper that in overall, people agreed. The main argument was "if it is for our security...". These people probably never entered an airport. I beg your courage to stand against such stupid laws that doesn't serve any democratic interest.If you do not agree with me, watch out to avoid bringing any liquid if you want to jump in my car. Unless you show me the evidence it's more dangerous to have liquids in a plane than in a car. But I'm really not convinced.(P.S: Don't worry, from now on I will always have bottles of water in my car for selling at 5 euros each, just in case you may be thirsty).

item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Comme vous avez pu le voir dans les deux derniers posts, ma copine Mari était de passage à Madrid, chez moi, du 3 au 14 janvier.C'était génial de l'accueillir ici, de lui faire partager les endroits que j'arpente jour après jour; les transports en commun, ma faculté, mes bars préférés, ...Et quel plaisir de regoûter après 3 mois à ses petits plats japonais exquis! Difficile de se remettre à la nourriture belgo-espagnole après ça!
J'avais un peu peur au début car j'avais beaucoup de boulot, mais finalement, j'ai quand même pu m'arranger pour travailler.C'est que quand il y a une motivation, je peux me mettre à bosser immédiatement. Alors qu'un jour normal, il me faut une heure avant de commencer, sans compter les pauses pendant ;-)Mais tout s'est très bien passé. Juste jeudi 11 janvier où j'ai du la laisser s'occuper toute la journée car j'avais des cours importants à l'université. Elle en a profité pour faire un peu de shopping ;-)Elle m'a vraiment gâté pour mon anniversaire (le 12 janvier). Mais elle vous racontera elle-même cette journée (m'a-t-elle dit). Je peux juste vous dire qu'elle m'a offert un beau pull en laine et un beau porte-feuille, tous deux de Tokyo. La classe... :-)English version below

Technorati Tags: Happy, madrid, Mari

As you might have seen in the two last posts, my girlfriend Mari was in Madrid, in my home, from the third to the 14th of January.It was really great to welcome her here. To share with here all these paths I take day after day;the public transportation, my faculty, my favorite bars, ...And what a pleasure to enjoy, after 3 months, her so sweet Japanese food! Quite difficult to eat after that some belgo-spanish food!Although I was a bit afraid at the beginning since I had a lot of work to do during her presence, everything turned to be ok.I managed to find time to work. The thing is that when there is a source of motivation, I need one tenth the time I use to need to work! :-)So, everything was really ok. Solely Thursday 11th of January, I had to let her alone all day long since I had important courses at the university. She took advantage of this to make some shopping ;-)It was really like a puff of fresh air to see her again and live with her here. I really thank her because I know that it is all but an easy thing to come from Tokyo to Madrid, and I know that she worked hard on weekends for her plane ticket.I'm really a lucky guy.

item.title: Report on the DB1 course
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
That post's aim is to show the matter we saw during the three-week intensive course of database 1.That way, the next teacher coming from Madrid or whatsoever may know from where will he have to start.

Technorati Tags: burundi, ngozi, database, tedeco

I taught to the second year of the computer science degree (a four-year degree). It was all the morning during 3 weeks.The first week we saw the overall topic of databases. When do we need them? What do they provide?We also saw the ANSI multi layers architectures with plenty of examples to illustrate their inter-independence.And we briefly talked about the 2 first data architectures (in arborescence and in network).The second week we saw the relational model. We explained the concept of the tables and we dug into the relational algebra. By the end of the week we've started to translate the algebra to the SQL language.We eventually finished the SQL language (we saw the INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE queries, plus the SELECT with conditions, jointures, grouping, aggregation functions such as MIN(), MAX(), SUM(), AVG(), ordering, limits and subqueries).We have just omitted the DATE relative SQL functions.We also talked about the integrity management (why it's important? Why it's far better to apply integrity checks directly in the DBMS and not in the application's side). We saw the Cascade strategy and the SET NULL one.Last week, we have practised on SQL queries and we talked about the normal forms. As you might see, we didn't had time to talk about the inner advanced features of the DBMS such as indexes and clusters.As a remainder, here is the correction of the exam the student passed the Thursday of the third week.

item.title: Toilettes japonaises
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Décidément, ces japonais ils sont sacrément ingénieux! Voyez cela;En Europe, nous avons habituellement dans nos toilettes un petit lavabo sur le côté pour se laver les mains.Ca prend de la place, et ça utilise de l'eau. Normal me direz-vous!Les Japonais eux ont trouvé l'idée géniale: ils mettent le lavabo juste au dessus du réservoir de la toilette.Ainsi, une fois que vous tirez la chasse, hop le réservoir se rempli en passant par le robinet et vous avez largement le temps de vous laver les mains!Gain de place, et économie d'eau! Fallait y penser!
Autre astuce, mais cette fois plus technologique; le mini jet qui vous nettoie le cul.Un simple petit bouton et hop, un petit jet vise juste au bon endroit (pour autant que vous soyez normalement constitué). Le gros bouton rond permet de régler la pression. Au maximum, ça arrache; faites gaffe!Sur les modèles de luxe, il y a même un bouton "sèche cheveux" pour terminer le travail en beauté.C'est pas beau tout ça?En tout cas, je vous jure que c'est très agréable et que l'essayer, c'est l'adopter.Si la première idée pourrait facilement se développer en Europe, la seconde paraît plus difficile à mettre en oeuvre dans la mesure où aucune de nos toilettes ne dispose d'une prise de courant. Mais si vous construisez une nouvelle maison, pensez à demander à l'électricien d'en installer une! Vous ne le regretterez pas :-)

1) The course is structured2) The explanations were clear3) The teacher answer to my questions4) The tests are concordant with the matter we saw during the class5) The tests are easy6) In average, I spent X hours to study for each test7) The content of the course is coherent (the order and the goal of the different themes )8) The class is boring9) According to me, the class was too slow (1) or too fast (5)10) The teacher can get the attention of the audience 11) In overall, I would rate the course X/10 and the teacher Y/10They had to answer on a blank page without putting their names. It was anonymous (in order to have real critics).And I promised I won't have a look at the results before being in the plane.

I love it.
This is all in a web2.0 fashion where power is shifted to individuals.

Nowadays you should better pay attention to your reputation because
anyone could make a dent to it!

And I think it is a great trend because before companies would only
respect very high profile clients or media representatives. .
And I know what I'm talking about because I used to use the privilege
of owning a media (distributed in 30k copies in Belgium). Strangely
enough, most of client services were taking a special care of us.
Now they will have to take care of everybody. That's much more fair.

item.title: Democracy 2.0 - Because we need a new system to cope with today's new challenges
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
"Democracy: a system of government by the whole population or all the eligible members of a state, typically through elected representatives"Today we are facing challenges that are bigger than us: the climate crisis and the financial crisis. Our governments are mainly unable to cope with these new challenges. For the majority of them, they are stuck with short term decisions. They spend tax payers' money to save failed industries.We need to rethink our democraciesOur Occidental democracies are based on paper. Political parties are sending their program on paper. Citizens vote on paper. But paper is expensive. Paper takes time to be printed and more importantly paper are essentially a one-way communication channels.As a result, citizens can only vote every 5 years or so. In the time in between, they have little interaction with their representatives. As our memories used to be short, they can basically do whatever except during the last 6 months before an election.
In current democracies, there are almost no interaction with citizens and with expert. Collaboration is limited.

Voting paper can't be personalized On top of that, paper cannot be personalized. Every single citizen, whether he is a worker or a non-worker, a youngster or an old person, get the same paper. They all have to answer the same questions. They all have to vote for the same people. And as every human, these people are good for some subjects but can't be good for solving all the different issues we are facing as a society.I would love that our governments ask us much more our thinking. But they can't do it on paper. It is too expensive and they would need to spend too much time to educate the whole population to make sure they can take a good decision (look at all the debates about the European Constitution in France!).What I want is a clever democracy. I don't wanna be asked about what to do regarding agriculture policies (I'm not a farmer), I don't wanna be asked about what to do regarding education at this time (I'm not a teacher, I have no kids). But, I do wanna be asked about what to do to foster entrepreneurship, about what to do make our institutions more efficient. For the rest, I trust my fellow citizens who are more directly impacted or have time to dig into the subject.You can't ask to everybody their thinking about everything. But this remains unthinkable in our current democracies.It's not about left and right wing anymore, it's about communitiesPeople used to gather behind this simple paradigm: you are whether a socialist (left wing) or a liberal (right wing). But this leads to useless competition and decisions based on the politic party you support instead of your real skills to fit the job as a leader.This means that our leaders don't have to collaborate with the best people out there to make our society work better. They have to compete, they have to be winners and make the other lose next elections.

In a Democracy 2.0, Citizens could participate in chosen topics

From parliament members to community managersWhat we need is leaders that will collaborate with people expert in their field. We need leaders who won't pretend to be able to give answers to all subjects of our society. Tomorrow's new leaders need be closer of their communities. They need to foster the debates, be more transparent, in one word; they need to be "Community managers".

In a Democracy 2.0, parliament members should ask as Community Managers

Democracy 1.0 relies on paper, Democracy 2.0 will use the Internet as the new paperToday we have a new technology at hand: The Internet. For the first time in human history, we can put together a majority of citizens through a two-way communication channel. Why not using this to build a new paradigm of democracy?It is cheap and it allows personalisation. Citizens would be able to choose in which subjects they are mostly interested. They will not be bothered with unfamiliar topics. But they will have a lot of things to say to things which would impact them directly.

item.title: Commentag introduces tweetag.com
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded: This Wednesday 19th of November, Commentag introduced a brand new way to search on Twitter.Twitter is platform where more than 3 million people post short messages about what they are doing or thinking.It's exactly like your status on facebook except that here most of them are totally public and anyone can follow your updates.This frenzy ecosystem can be visualized live on the brillant TwitterVision.Wouldn't it be cool if we could tell what all these people are most talking about?To do so, you can use the impressive Twitscoop. It analyzes words frequencies and gives you the hottest trends live. That's cool.But what if you want to know what all these people on twitter have to say about, let's say, Obama?Twitscoop is not gonna be of any help here.Instead, you can do a search on search.twitter.com. A search for Obama will bring you all the tweets talking about Obama in real-time.That's cool!But you're probably not going to read all the tweets, there are too many!Let's go back to my first question: "What people have to say about Obama?".Reading the first 10 tweets of the result list will not give you any clue to answer that question.Indeed, the 10 last persons who published a thought about Obama may not represent the topics that have been discussed lately!That's exactly where Tweetag stands.Insteadof having to read everything to get a picture of a conversation,Tweetag applies Commentag technologies to allow you to easily catch upany discussion about a topic of interest.Try it out by yourself!You may also want to read the review of Techcrunch about Tweetag.

item.title: Last week at Ngozi university
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
I didn't take the time to write new post quite often this week.The truth is I was quite busy.As every Monday, my student had to pass a test.I'm definitely an exigent teacher. Although I should adapt me to the local level, I didn't lower my exigencies.I always want to ask my students clever questions that make them thinking.For me, there is nothing more stupid to ask things they have as it is in their notes.It's like asking a copy and paste of a Word document. Even a no-brainer can do that.But it turns out that this kind of question perturb a lot of students. They are definitely not used to it over here.When they previously had a programmation course, they just add to change a few lines of a code proposed by the teacher. They were always directed to the answer the prof was expecting.

That Monday, I asked to my second group (DB2) a code to print a descendant list of number from 100 to 0.We only saw the ascendant order (ie: the easiest for-boucle) in class. And not only it was the first time for them they had to write a code instead of just adding one or two statements, but they also had to think a bit. It may appear ridiculously simple for us, but it wasn't for them.But still, in overall they made it quite well. The average of the class was 11,9/20.Today, it was the exam.And I asked this (to my second class).- Given an entity-relation diagram representing journalists (with attributes id, name, sex, birthyear) and articles (with attributes reference,titre, rubric, text, year),1) Write a html form to let users fill the different attributes2) Write a php script to show the following result:"The journalist X was just added successfully" but since this sentence in french is genre-sensitive, they had to print a different answer according to the sex of the journalist entered.They also had to show as many images of a candle as the age of the new journalist (ie: they had to implement a for-boucle on the starting at the yearbirth of the journalist, ending at 2007).Finally, and as a bonus, they had to print a SQL query using the data entered by the user in order to add the new journalist in the database.To my first class (DB1) I asked:- given the same diagram, give the relational diagram. If you use foreign keys, precise the strategy for keeping the integrity.- Fill the tables you have obtained and give two SQL queries to add a tuple in each of them.- Give a SQL Query:

item.title: Palais Royal au parti socialiste français
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Nouvelle qui n'en est pas:Ségolène Royal représentera le PS en 2007.
Tout ce débat au PS français pour élire leur candidat(e) fut ma foi assez grotesque.3 candidats: DSK, Fabius et Ségolène.Malgré que les sondages, et ce depuis le début, ne laissaient planer aucun doute (on parlait de 55% pour Ségo, 15 et 5% pour les 2 autres), la réticence de laisser le pouvoir à une femme a prévalu.Bravo. 20 sur 20.Résultat des courses: c'est quand même Ségo qui va représenter le parti. Mais un parti qui aura, une fois de plus, montrer tout sauf une cohérence et une unité.Pour le fun, faisons un peu de prognostiques grâce aux... mathématiques :) (on arrête pas le progrès)Partons de l'hypothèse qu'en France, 60% des votants sont de gauche, et 40% de droite.A gauche, il y aura au premier tour des présidentielles, 10 candidats (Ségo, Besancenot, José Bové, les verts, les communistes, ...).A droite, il y aura 2 voire 3 candidats.A l'extrême droite, qu'un seul candidat.

Bref, Le Pen fera comme en 2002: 16,86%Il reste 88% à partager entre la droite et la gauche.60% de 88% = 52,8% pour la gauche.40% de 88% = 35,2% pour la droite.Ceux qui ont voté les petits candidats de gauche en 2002, continueront à faire pareille. Prenons 4% de moyenne pour les petits candidats (de fait, en 2002, les résultats ont été de 5% pour les verts, 5% pour Arlette Laguiller, 3,3% pour Robert Hue, et 4,25% pour Besancenot pour ne citer que les "principaux").On avait 10 candidats.Donc 9 petits (et je suis gentil): 9*4% = 36%Il reste donc 52,8% - 36% = 16,8% des votants au premier tour pour Ségolène.Soit moins que le score virtuel de Le Pen.Et la droite?Bein eux ils sont pas con. Ils ont créé l'UMP. Avec un U pour union.Ils ont compris comme les belges (sauf quelques flamands) que l'Union fait la force.Du coup des 35,2% qui restent pour la droite, ils seront partagés qu'en 3 voire 4. Dont un principal.Prenons toujours 4% de moyenne pour les candidats de second plan et on se retrouve avec 20% pour le candidat principal Sarkozy (soit le score de Chirac au premier tour de 2002).Voilà comment on se retrouve avec un pays géré par un parti de droite alors que le peuple est majoritairement de gauche.Vous avez dit "démocratie"?notes:1)Tous les chiffres précités ne sont que de pures simulations. Mais à chaque fois, j'ai été généreux pour la gauche. Ils démontrent mathématiquement que le résultat des urnes sera connu dès la publication de la liste des candidats.2) Mais pourquoi dans les sondages TF1 Ségolène l'emporte sur Sarkozy?Car dans les sondages on demande aux français qui ils préfèrent entre DEUX candidats. Comme en 2002, les médias se focalisent sur un deuxième tour totalement virtuel.3) Que faire?Plusieurs propositions:3.1. Obligation de vote (comme en Belgique).La meilleure loi démocratique pour moi. Les gens qui ne vont pas voter (parce qu'il fait beau par exemple), ne sont pas des électeurs de Le Pen et de petits candidats. Car ceux là savent que chaque vote compte. Du coup, au plus l'absentéisme est grand, au plus il profite aux extrêmes et aux petits candidats.3.2. Revoir le système à deux tours.Pourquoi ne pas choisir 3 candidats pour le 2e tour?4) Un français m'a dit: Oui mais je partage plus les idées de Besancenot que de Royal.Je peux comprendre. Mais bon, ça te fait une belle jambe de voter Besancenot au premier tour et de devoir voter Sarkozy au second tour. C'est super.Bref mon message:Petits candidats, pour le bien de la France, retirez votre candidature.Mettez votre orgueil de côté et combattez au sein d'une union de gauche pour que votre voix soit entendue au sein de d'une gauche au pouvoir. Tout le monde a à y gagner.

item.title: Second lesson day at Ngozi university
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Here we are.You are all waiting for the next story isn't it?Is Xavier tuckered out his second day? What an unsustainable suspense! At least you can imagine that I'm still alive since I wrote these lines.So, I woke up at 6:30am. I slept much better than the previous night since I used my earmuffs to avoid the neighbor's radio at 5 and the cock at 4:30 ;-)But still, I wasn't like totally ok. I was still a bit tired.I took my (damn) cold shower and my breakfast. Then, to the university. I took a taxi bicycle for 150F (less than 0,15€). It was quite funny since the first driver told me "it's 50,000F!", well tried dude ;-)With that "transportation", I need (only) half time to get to the university (10 minutes).
I tried to photocopy the notes of a student that had the course Databases 1 last year.That simple task that should require 37 seconds, took 30 times more! ;-)Anyway. The thing is that the students told me yesterday that I should give them notes.Wow. I didn't know that. Mariano told me that it was quite difficult to make copies, and therefore, that the best is to let student take notes during the class.The point is that they are not used to take notes on the fly. So, today I started to say exactly what they have to write since I don't have any syllabus in french here. And I just can't do such a syllabus here. It's definitely too much work and I don't have time here to do that.So, this is one important thing for the followers. You should prepare a (short) syllabus in french (or english, but their english level is quite low) so that you already know exactly what do you have to spell them out.Because what I do now is just putting my explanations with sentences to be written. But I have to do it on the fly.So at the end, the students have to structure their notes themselves. Which is obvious for us, but not necessarily for them.

So, this morning I've just used the white board. I've started by asking someone to explain briefly what we saw yesterday. It was not that bad actually although I had to precise some little things.Then I kept on with the relational structure of databases and its formalism with mathematics (Relational Algebra).After 4 hours, we just finished the Selection function on the set of tuples. It's quite not a fast velocity but it's ok. It took time because I gave everybody (they were only 20 this morning) a chance to go in front of the white board. Which is definitely the best way to ensure that they understand. But when I see backward all the energy, the time, the amount of explanations needed to achieve that, I just can't imagine how should it be if it was in a foreign language. If it is only about practising, then it's definitely ok, but if you have to explain concepts that are not straight-forward, it should be much more difficult.At 10h, there is normally what is known as the Tea-break. But actually there was no tea at all at the university. Argh, so I kept with water. After two hours of talking, you really need to drink. Just imagine after 8 hours. The result? 1,5 liters a day, just between 8am and 6pm! ;-)One thing that surprises me is that the student of the third course who already attended the Databases1 class last year, are following my class like the others. Almost like if they've never had any lesson on that topic. The thing is that not only they've never done any practise on that topic, but they just don't have any practise at all. Most of them just couldn't explain what's a server, what's a client (now they can). So, I took time to explain them these "basic" things and I think it worths the time it takes.They still have a lot to learn, but although the tren is very slow I'm confident it is on good tracks. And for me this far most important than achieving reaching the next train station.The afternoon I've made an introduction to the HTML language. Although it's not the purpose of the course DB2, it was a necessary evil in order to give them all the tools they will have to use for their project.At the end of the 4 hours, they were all able to create a very simple html page. You can't imagine all the obstacles we had to pass through to achieve that. For most of them, it was their very first time they open Internet Explorer.It's 11:22pm and I'm gonna stop my post here since it's time to sleep. item.title: Pronostiques élections françaises
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Il y a 4 mois, je faisais une petite simulation mathématique pour pronostiquer le résultat des élections françaises d'avril 2007.Le but étant à l'époque surtout de mettre en garde nos voisins d'ouest sur les raisons du Le Pen au second tour en 2002.A à un mois des élections, force est de constater que beaucoup de choses ont évoluées depuis novembre dernier.Dont quelque chose que je n'avais absolument pas imaginé; la montée en puissance du centre (et de François Bayrou).
D'un premier côté, Sarko s'est mis fort à droite afin d'essayer de séduire les électeurs du FN (probablement par opportunisme en voyant leur excellent résultat en 2002, ce qui est une erreur car il est avéré qu'un grand nombre de ces électeurs ne sont pas réellement de l'extrême droite mais sont juste des votes contestataires).De l'autre, Ségolène s'avère être une très mauvaise candidate (on ne compte plus ses bêtises en public).Bref, un trou énorme s'est créé au centre et Bayrou l'exploite à merveille.

Tags: bayrou, France, politique, présidentielles, ségolène, soleil

Au niveau du nombre de candidats (base de ma simulation de novembre), on se retrouve à 12.Dont 3 candidats de droite, et 8 de gauche.Du coup, on aura comme en 2002 un gros problème pour le PS puisque les voix de gauche seront éparpillées.Donc si on se base uniquement sur l'éparpillement des voix, ce seront Bayrou et Sarko qui passeront.Car ce sont les deux candidats qui visent un spectre assez large et peu partagé. Ils ne subiront donc aucune dilution de leurs parts de marché lorsque les gens devront choisir entre non pas 3 ou 4 candidats, mais les 12. Alors que Ségo subira cette dilution. La surprise pourrait encore venir de Le Pen qui pourrait prendre la place de Sarko si ce dernier continue d'essayer de séduire l'original.

item.title: Mon arrivée à Madrid
item.dc:creator: Xavier Damman
item.content:encoded:
Finalement je suis venue à madrid après 14h30 de vol.Je suis très contente d'être ici :D
Hier, on a été au parc Retiro, on s'est promené.Il fait pas froid ici, j'avais pas besoin d'apporter autant de vêtements :(Le soir, c'est moi qui ait cuisiné, mais à cause du décalage horaire, j'étais fatiguée... :(C'est vraiment chiant le décalage horaire, c'est pas cool.Mais bon, on peut rien y faire.Aujourd'hui, on a été à Segovia !Mais malgré mon attente, il y avait pas grand chose à voir.C'était un peu dommage :(
Plaza Mayor avec la vue sur la cathédraleOn a été à l'aqueduc, à la plaza mayor, et l'alcazar.Mais c'était agréable de se promener sous le soleil quand même, il y a le soleil toujours en Espagne !! (pas comme en Belgique, lol)
Segovia, c'est une ville anciene et nouvelle.L'aqueduc, il est à côté du restaurant, mais il est là depuis 2000 ans !Je me suis demandé ce qu'il avait vu jusqu'à maintenant.Est-ce qu'il a vu la guerre? La mort? Le progrès de la civilisation?J'avais des sentiments mêlés en le regardant.
La vue de l'alcazar, c'était superbe :DPlusieurs collines s'étendaient devant nous, c'était beau!On est rentrés au kot à 18h, c'était une très belle journée.Comme ça, nos derniers 2 jours se sont bien passés.Je suis très heureuse d'être ici.Quel bonheur!J'espère que le temps se passe lentement jusqu'au 14.A bientôt!
